d: Red pepper for the slow ass: man tries it on himself.
a: When, on the advice of a friend, he gives the ass red pepper, the ass runs away. Then he tries it on himself. He runs so fast that he passes the ass. Arriving at home, he says to his wife, "Unload the ass when he comes. I must run through the village a couple of times more."

d: Man interrupted each time he tries to eat something.
Man continually interrupted from eating answers in rhymed monosyllables.

r: (Cf. +G60.) *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 257 No. 193; Italian Novella: Rotunda. Cf. Japanese: Ikeda.
a: A man eats up the dried meat of a Jew on shipboard. It happens that the Jew is carrying his dead father back home for burial in this form.

d: The dream of marking the treasure.
r: *Wesselski Arlotto II 267 No. 216, Hodscha Nasreddin I 278 No. 314; Lithuanian: Balys Legends No. 788f.; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
a: A man dreams that he finds treasure and that he marks the spot with his excrements. Only the latter part of the dream is true.

d: Man dreams that he is rich.
a: Finds cat's excrements.

d: Pig licks sleeping man's lips: man thinks he is being kissed.
Wager with overdressed youths that servant can carry a large bucket of water upstairs.
a: They follow and are soaked when the servant purposely spills the dirty water.

d: Woman exposed to ridicule when her wig is snatched off by a monkey.
Man given ride on a hemp-dresser.

a: Besides the motifs which follow, the entire series of motifs concerning fools (+J1700 +J2799) properly belongs here as well as where it is given.

d: Deaf persons: search for the lost animal.
a: A inquires for his lost animal. B talks about his work and makes a gesture. A follows the direction of the gesture and happens to find the animals. He returns and offers an injured animal to B in thanks. B thinks that he is blamed for injuring the animals. Dispute. Taken to deaf judge.

d: Deaf peasant: travelers ask the way.
a: Travelers ask their direction. Peasant thinks they want to buy oxen. Peasant's wife arrives; thinks they say her food is too salty. Daughter-in-law and father-in-law misunderstand each other.

d: Two persons believe each other deaf.
r: *Type 1698C; *Aarne FFC XX 29ff.; Wesselski Gonnella 118 No. 16; Nouvelles Ricriations No. 10; Nouvelles de Sens No. 4.
a: A trickster tells each of two persons before they meet that the other is hard of hearing and must be shouted at. A great shouting takes place, and each thinks the other out of his wits.
Lord: Good morning, Peter. Peasant: I come from Bingen. L. What is the hog worth? P. Two weeks from next Sunday (the wedding). L. Shall I come to the wedding? P. Three and a half gulden.
Lord: Good day, Caspar. Caspar: I am making a reel. L. Good day, Caspar. C. It is worth four pence. L. Good day, Caspar. C. Yes, my lord, whenever you wish.

d: The deaf man and the proud nobleman.
a: A nobleman amuses himself at the expense of the deaf man. Finally Nobleman: I wish you a thousand gallows and ropes around your neck. Peasant: My lord, I wish you twice as many.

d: Misunderstood words lead to comic results.
r: Type 1698G; Aarne FFC XX 40, 76. Spanish: Espinosa Jr.
a: In some the people are not really deaf but fail to catch a word; in some they are deaf.

d: The deaf man with the bird in the tree.
a: A traveller asks the way and the man keeps telling him about the bird he has caught. (The questions and answers often rhyme.)
He plans the conversation with the expected answers. The answers turn out otherwise. A. How are you? B. I am dead. Thank God! What have you eaten? Poison, I think. I hope it agrees with you.
"A woodchopper." The workman answers the traveler's courtesies with remarks about his work.
The youth answers unintelligibly but is praised nevertheless.
The drunken priest says, "In the morning I take a drink of rum and afterwards four or five little drinks."

d: Deaf litigants and deaf judge misunderstand one another.

a: One asks name of town; another replies, "This is Wesley." Another says, "I thought it was Thursday." Third says, "So am I; let's have a drink."

d: Deaf husband orders deaf wife to prepare a certain dish: misunderstanding.
Misunderstanding and quarrels in family of deaf.

r: Sees two plates where there are one, etc. Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 186 No. 358.

d: The squint-eyed son and the bottle.
a: Sent by his father to get the only bottle of rare wine, he sees two. Not wishing to show his father to be a liar, he breaks one really the only one.

d: One-eyed man as appraiser of horse.
a: Has appraised it at half a mark. "He saw only half a horse; otherwise he would have valued it at a mark."
Man asks bull if he is on the right road. Bull butts him and knocks him down. The man says that all that was not necessary, simply to say yes or no.

d: Blind man reaches his home hanging on ox's tail (or in other ridiculous situation).
Nearsighted knight mistakes own servant for one of the enemy.
a: Runs lance into his posterior.

d: Blind man strikes woman thinking she is buffalo.
Blind son-in-law visits his wife's family: gets into difficulties.
Blind men trying to kill pigs with clubs strike one another.
Blind man in awkward position pretends to see.

r: U.S.: *Baughman; Danish: MS in Danske Folkemindesamling (Grundtvig No. 166).
a: Each member has mouth turned in a different way. Unavailing attempts to blow out the light.

d: Man calls convention of all long noses.
Each of four stutterers thinks the others are ridiculing him.

a: Amusing results.

d: Blind, lame, and deaf as witnesses in court.
Dwarf king falls into porridge-pot at court of human king.
Dwarf poet forced to swim in drinking-horn of human being.
Tiny ambassador put on horse with long stirrups.
a: Cannot say anything as he is too busy trying to keep his seat.

d: Short magistrate wears a high helmet.
Lame man taken on hunt in wheel chair beats the dogs home when they tree a spook or when a bear gets after them.
Audience of one hired to listen to egoistic dismal-voiced singer.
Six short, fat husbands married to six tall, fat wives try absurdly to kiss them at the threshold on their wedding day.
Fat man so unwieldly he fishes from his window in the street.

r: Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 785; Fb "mshller" II 649; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

a: Baker cannot understand how a man who has been a miller can be a beggar. It is a wonder that the farmers are not beggars instead.
If he had been like the rest of the congregation he would have become rich.
A mad dog in place of a miller in a sack.
Drunken millers force monks to dance. Millers are enticed to monastery and beaten.
Sews the stolen piece of cloth on the outside of his coat, thinking that it is on the inside.

d: Thievish tailor cuts a piece of his own coat.
Thieving tailor can hide stolen cloth even in needle-and-thread tube.
Tailors cowards as warriors: go home to their needles.
Butcher wonders that man who has been buying his meat for seven years can still be alive.
Ugly cobbler continually threatens to throw his last at people.
a: The object of jokes.

d: Shoemaker drinks more than his portion of "drink of lies", which has been prepared for all to partake of equally.
r: Wienert FFC LVI 39; Halm Aesop No. 136.

d: Jokes about other artisans and tradesmen.

a: Devils annoyed at their noisy trade.

d: Client flees when cobwebs are brought in to medicate cuts.
Barber uses cut hair to staunch cuts.
Talkativeness of the fishwives of Paris.
a: Anecdotes of their invective.

d: What will happen when there are so many lawyers.
a: Woman sees the crowds of students in the law school. She knows that the one lawyer in her village has ruined nearly everyone.

d: Beggar frightens lawyer into giving by telling him of all the lawyers in hell.
r: Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 95 No. 819*; cf. U.S.: Baughman.

d: Dying like Christ between two thieves.
r: U.S.: Baughman; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 134 No. 1583*.
a: The dying man has the lawyer and the notary stand on either side of him.

d: Lawyer who tries to practice without lying fails.
r: *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 127; Crane Vitry 155 No. 52; Scala Celi 7b No. 47; Alphabet No. 483.
a: He enters religious order and tries to conduct the legal business without lying.

r: Crane Vitry 150 No. 40; Scala Celi 7b No. 45; Mensa Philosophica No. 148.

d: Nero has reserved place in hell for lawyers.
r: Crane Vitry 148 No. 36; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

d: Lawyer thrown back into mud when rescuers learn that he is a lawyer.
Lawyer loses tongue in death because he sold it in life.
Eloquent lawyer makes obviously guilty client doubt his own guilt.
Guilty of everything connected with the seven senses.
a: When the priest to whom he is confessing says there are but five senses, the magistrate says that he needs two more senses than other people.

d: Foreigner wonders why city with so many judges has not been destroyed.
Music teacher charges double for those who have taken music before.
a: One fee for teaching and one for making them forget the old teaching.

d: Master of seven liberal arts begs from wagoner.
a: With his one art latter supports his family.

d: Doctor cures palpitation of heart: patient stops breathing.
Head cut off to cure snakebite.
Eyedrops prescribed for stomach ache so that patient can see what he eats.
Man with cheeks stuffed with food operated on to remove swellings.
Doctor called to attend sick man immediately gives orders for the funeral.

r: *Types 1725 1824; **Kristensen Vore Fzhdres Kirketjeneste (Aarhus, 1899); *Fb "przhst" II 884a; West Indies: Flowers 583.

d: Parson put to flight during his sermon.
Sexton's dog steals sausage from parson's pocket: parson flees.
Sexton puts needle in sacramental bread: parson sticks his hand.
Sexton arranges wasp-nest so that parson sits on it.
a: Wasps chase him.

d: Tame bear tied to church bells.
a: Rings alarm.

d: One-eyed parson in dimly lighted church joins the wrong couples.
a: Marries the old man to the girl and the old woman to the boy.
He wants to show how Christ rode into Jerusalem. Sexton sticks ox with needle.
Locked in church all week by mistake. When the congregation comes, the hog runs between the parson's legs and carries him out.

d: Parson preaches so that half the congregation weeps and half laughs.
a: Has clothes torn in the back. Those that see this laugh. He wins the wager.

d: Parson smears his hand with butter.
a: Rascals have spread butter on the altarbread. The parson preaches, "What is the life of man?" and therewith brings his hand down on the altar-bread: "Pure butter!"

d: Parson is to let a dove fly in the church.
a: It dies in his pocket.

d: At the blessing of the grave the parson's ox breaks loose: "Now the devil has him."
The corpse with his feet cut off.
a: The coffin-maker has fitted him to the coffin. The parson: "On the last day he will arise." One of the coffin-makers: "Did I say that?"

r: *Type 1791; *BP III 395; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 82; Scala Celi 101b No. 547; Alphabet No. 333; U.S., England: *Baughman; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1791, Legends No. 889.
a: A sexton hears thieves in the cemetery cracking nuts and thinks it is the devil cracking bones. With the gouty parson on his back he comes upon the thieves who, thinking it is their companion with the sheep, call out, "Is he fat?" The sexton: "Fat or lean, here he is!"

d: Robbers mistake man for devil (the "sheep" speaks, "Gently, gently!")
The parson who said there is no devil.
a: The bear-showman lets the bear climb up the pulpit. The parson thinks the bear is the devil.

d: If his son were only a fool he would let him study to be a priest.
a: So says the innkeeper.

d: A bad year for priests: few funerals.
a: All but the priest rejoice over the good health of the community. He bemoans his loss of income from burials.

d: Enmity between priests and monks: chickens and eggs.
a: Monks eat eggs and make chickens expensive; priests eat hens and make eggs high.

d: The hungry parson and the porridge-pot.
a: Overnight at the peasant's house. The hungry parson hunts the porridge in the dark, guided by a rope the sexton has given him. Series of accidents.

d: Stupid man tries to take honey from jug at night while visiting.
a: Series of accidents.

d: The parson put out of countenance.
The large loaves need a large oven.
a: Parson says that the loaves with which Jesus fed the people in the wilderness were as large as the mountains. The mason asks what kind of oven they were baked in.
The parson asks the boy: "What does your father say when you begin to eat?" Boy: "You young devil, etc."
Makes a present application of the words of the parson.
Boy: "Pay your old debts." Variants: (a) What evil did Adam do? He (shoemaker) made my shoes too small. (b) What kind of man was Moses? He was a day laborer.
"He stayed to hold the oxen."

d: Parson: Where was Christ when he was neither in heaven nor on earth?
a: He was in the willow-grove looking for a stick to beat those who ask foolish questions.

d: Names of persons in the Trinity.
a: The priest's example: the three cows. The boy: "The Holy Ghost has just had a calf."
A boy rides with a rich man. Goes into church and leaves his coat lying on the sled. When the parson preaches about the rich man who went to hell, the boy calls out, "Then he took my coat along!"

d: The parson sings like a goat.
r: *Type 1834; Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 243 No. 539; *Crane Vitry 157 No. 56; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 576; Fb "przhdiken" II 882; Scala Celi 25a No. 164; Italian Novella: Rotunda; India: Thompson-Balys.
a: The parson sees an old woman weeping and believes that she is touched by his singing. When spoken to she says that she has been reminded of her old goat which she has lost.

d: The dream: all parsons in hell.
a: The smith tells the parson whom he has summoned that he has dreamed of going to heaven where St. Peter would not admit him before he saw a parson. There were no parsons in heaven, but all in hell.
Devout woman and a priest retell their dreams. The priest has dreamed that all the devout women are to be found in hell.
Parson intones instructions to the sexton (cook) as a part of the mass.

r: Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 2451*; Rumanian: Schullerus FFC LXXVIII No. 1777*.
a: Rector confesses his sacristan: "Have you drunk the wine designated for the mass?" "I can't hear you." Exchange of places. Sacristan asks rector: "Have you kissed my wife?" "Really, I can't hear you."
Bell breaks and priest's patron whistles in place of ringing the bell at mass.

d: Parson refreshes himself during the sermon.
Parson takes a drink of liquor during the sermon.
Parson takes a chew of tobacco during the sermon.
Cock crows at church and the sexton awakes and begins to sing.
The parson has no need to preach.
a: Those who know may teach those who don't know.

d: No need to give sermon about saint again.
r: *Wesselski Arlotto I 188 No. 8; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
a: "Last year I told you all about his life and works. He has performed no new miracles."
Refuses to say, "I'm not worthy" at communion.

d: Chapel endowed with fifty blows for the friar.
Bishop willing to admit castrated man as monk: wishes all were in the same condition.
Man heeds what he thinks to be call to the ministry.
Young man plowing corn sees letters "P.  C." formed by clouds.
a: He explains situation to minister, asks to be ordained. The minister explains that the letters mean "plow corn" instead of "preach Christ".

d: Fortune-teller shows others how to get rich but remains poor himself.
r: (Cf. +J1062.) Herbert III 22 No. 186; Crane Vitry 250 No. 266.

a: Custom not to bury dead until someone has something good to say about him. No one will praise a dead usurer until a barber is willing to say that he had a good beard.

r: Pauli (ed. Bolte) Nos. 193, 194; Crane Vitry 207 No. 179; Scala Celi 168b No. 959; Alphabet No. 792.
a: The parson asks the various trades and professions to rise one by one for a special blessing. When he calls for the usurers none reply.

d: Devil will not carry usurers to hell but will drag them by the legs.
r: Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 191; cf. Spanish: Espinosa Jr.
a: So declares a youth paid by a usurer to protest against the priest's remarks that the devil would carry all usurers off.

d: Only usurers can carry the corpse of the usurer.
r: (Cf. +X521.) Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 190; Irish: Beal XXI 326, cf. O'Suilleabhain 74.
a: It refuses to be moved by anyone else.

d: Usurer encourages sermons against usury, so that his competitors will cease activity.
Only prostitutes can carry the corpse of a prostitute.
Begging cripples hurry away from shrine lest they be healed and lose their livelihood.
Cohabitation between lunatics brought about for sport.
Man chased by bear to camp claims that he brought it in thus since he did not want to carry it.
How the Jews were drawn from heaven.
r: *Type 2403; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1868*; cf. U.S.: Baughman (+X597.1, +X902).
a: Someone cries, "Clothes are being auctioned off in hell."

d: Trickster breaks up Jewish marriage ceremony and seduces the bride.
Jokes concerning other races or nations.
Battle between lice of Strassburg and of Hungary.
r: Hungarians win. Wesselski Bebel II 149 No. 160.

a: A caretaker of an estate recently sold to a Bavarian sits among the swine so as to learn Bavarian.

r: Wienert FFC LVI 39; Halm Aesop No. 141.
a: Hermes and his wagon of lies break down in Arabia.

r: P. Sibillot and H. Gaidoz Le Blason Populaire de la France.
a: Despiteful names used by one city for another.
An order is read in church forbidding the young people to marry girls from other parishes.
On one side is a bundle of straw (her husband) and on the other a dog (her child). She gives the straw bundle a push and thereupon falls on the floor herself.

d: A youth promises to marry an old maid if she will sit all night on the roof.
a: She falls down.
One of the old maid's three teeth breaks off.

d: The wolf steals the old maid.
a: She keeps him for a husband.

d: The mother trains the old maid to speak properly.
a: Absurd results.

d: Drunk man lying under his bed thinks he is lying in his shroud.
a: Is cured of drunkenness.

d: Drunk man goes to the king and wants to buy an island.

a: Goes to sleep and never reaches it, though at home he praises the wedding.

d: Drunk men try to see one another home.
a: Absurd results.

d: Drunk man sees everything revolving and waits for his house to come to him.
Drunk woman thinks she is in heaven.
a: Hears someone play the lyre.

d: Drunk recruits make war on a haystack.
Drunken volunteer firemen bungle their work.

r: Chauvin V 278 No. 161; *BP II 371, 509; Ktshler-Bolte I 322; India: Thompson-Balys; Africa (Vai): Ellis 239 No. 46.
a: A man who tells but one lie a year is believed because of his general truthfulness. Amusing results.

d: Liar comes to believe his own lie.
a: He tells a lie so often that he believes it himself.

d: The teller reduces the size of his lie.
The liar reduces the size of his lie when his brother steps on his toes to remind him of his lying habits.
Liar reduces the size of his yarn when challenged.

r: Italian Novella: Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys; Japanese: Ikeda.
Type 1920C; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1920D*; Russian: Andrejev No. 1920D*; Prussian: Plenzat 78; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV 119 No. 27; Livonian: Loorits FFC LXVI 51 No. 89; India: *Thompson-Balys.

d: Greatest liar made king of Schlaraffenland.
Claim of property based on unusual lie.
The liar: "I have no time to lie today"; lies nevertheless.
r: Type 1920B; India: Thompson-Balys; Chinese: Eberhard FFC CXX 308ff.

d: Boy to deceive his uncle: induces uncle to climb tree before deception begins: this is the deception.
Would not lie for a trifle.
a: Liar tells of shooting large number of animals with one shot (an odd number, usually 99). When asked why he did not make it a round number (or an even hundred), he replies indignantly that he would not lie for one pigeon (rabbit).

d: Man has servant corroborate his lies.
a: Rewards him poorly. Servant exposes him.

d: The second liar corroborates the lie of the first.

r: (First ed. +X925.) Type 1920A; *BP II 371; Fb "vesterhav" III 1042b, "a" III 1187b; Indonesian: DeVries Volksverhalen II 377.
a: (Often with answer: "Many fried fish.")

d: Church member who has been called to task about his lying habits tells another lie in expressing his concern for his weakness.
a: He says he has shed barrels of tears because of his weakness.

d: The liar outdoes the tricksters who try to catch him in a lie.
a: He continues the lie the tricksters have made up to catch him.

d: Lie concerning babyhood and boyhood of hero.
Lie: persons with remarkable bodily parts.
Lie: great weight of large person.
Lie: great girth of large person.
Lie: remarkable person's physical powers and habits.
Lie: other motifs pertaining to extraordinary senses or bodily powers.
Elephant (camel) put in pocket as a curiosity to show friends.
Wind blows group of persons into woman's eye.
Lie: man ties up 700 camels in a corner of his sheet.
Beautiful girl seated on large lotus flower holding big elephant in each hand which she devours and throws off alternately.
Lie: child throws out elephant's carcass.

a: Hero marks logs by pinching a piece out of end of each one.

d: Man draws sixty (300) carts of wood.
Lie: hero responsible for topographical features (lakes, rivers, etc.).
Lie: hero breaking wen causes wall to fall down.

a: Man skins buffalo alive, turns them loose to grow new skins.
(John Henry.) Engages in contest with steam drill; he wins the contest but dies in the attempt.

d: Lie: man rides unusual riding animal (lion, deer, etc.).
Lie: person displays remarkable ingenuity or resourcefulness.
Lie: axes ground on boulders rolling down hill.
Lie: remarkable possessions of remarkable man.
Lie: remarkable clothing of remarkable man.
Lie: remarkable bouncing rubber boots (or the like).
Lie: other extraordinary personal effects of remarkable person.
Lie: extraordinary equipment of remarkable man.
Lie: extraordinary tools of remarkable man.
Lie: extraordinary machinery of remarkable man.

r: (First ed. +X1033.1.) Chauvin VII 57 No. 77; U.S.: *Baughman, *Folk-Say I 62.

d: Lie: remarkable equipment in big kitchen.
Lie: remarkable cooking in big kitchen.
Lie: remarkable baking in big kitchen.
Lie: skating with bacon to grease griddle in big kitchen.
Lie: other extraordinary foods from great kitchen.

r: French loggers prefer pea soup for all three meals. U.S.: Baughman.

d: Lie: extraordinary piles of garbage from great kitchen.
Lie: the great dining quarters (Paul Bunyan tales).
Lie: the great stable: distance to stall.
a: Cow has calf and the calf grows up and has calf before it can reach its stall.

d: Lie: other possessions of remarkable man.
Lie: great boat or ship of remarkable man.

a: Giant with sixty daughters.

r: (First ed. +X921.) *Types 1890 1909; Wesselski Mdrchen 226f.; Indonesia: DeVries's list No. 312.

d: Hunter shoots ram-rod full of ducks.
Hunter catches fish in boots while wading.
Man lays bag by fencehole and all the hares run into it.
Two hares run into each other and are caught.
Tiger lies in water with mouth open: cat drives fish in.
Large bag of frozen raccoons taken by hunter.
The rabbit-catch: rabbits freeze feet fast to ice at night.

a: Hunter cuts down tree packed full of animals. The tree is so full of animals that a crack in tree opens as animals inhale, closes when they exhale.

d: Lie: the great marksman's remarkable gun.
Lie: hunter shoots projectile great distance.
Lie: person shoots many animals with one shot.
Lie: ingenious person bends gun barrel to make spectacular shot.
Lie: the hunter catches or kills game by ingenious or unorthodox method.

r: (First ed. +X911.1.) Wesselski Bebel II 137 No. 115; U.S.: *Baughman.
a: He reaches down animal's throat, grasps his tail, and turns him inside out.

d: Accidental discharge of gun kills much game.
r: +X921.1.) Type 1890; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Friends 154 No. 21.
a: Gun kills a bird which falls on loose limb of tree, which falls on bear, etc., etc. (First ed.

d: Gunshot splits limb and catches feet of birds.
Hunting wolves with rod and line.
Game rolls down hill in snow; snowball builds up around game, keeps it fresh and protected until used.
Fruit tree grows from head of deer shot with fruit pits.
r: Compare M'nchhausen (1944) 32 (cherry tree). Canada, U.S.: *Baughman; India: Thompson-Balys.

d: Tree grows out of horse and gives rider shade.
Water of stream or lake freezes just as frogs jump into lake.
a: The frogs are caught in the ice.
Wolf's tail nailed to tree. Wolf runs away and leaves his skin hanging.

d: Lie: man uses remarkable means of getting out of tree stump.
Man escapes from bear by running for a long time, from summer to winter.
a: Bear chases man in July; he finally crosses a river on the ice. The bear falls in or stops following (in December).

d: Man in barrel grabs wolf by the tail and is drawn out of danger.
Animal unwittingly puts tail into man's hands and is caught.

r: (First ed. +X911.3.) Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 216 No. 48; West Indies: Flowers 585.
a: Trickster and companion are wolf hunting. The companion goes into the wolf hole. The wolf comes. The other catches the wolf by the tail and the wolf scratches dust into the companion's eyes. "What a dust." "If the wolf's tail breaks, you will see another kind of dust!"

d: Man escapes from bee's nest on bear's tail.
Tigers stand on each other's heads trying to reach man in tree.
a: His tears form a stream.

d: Lie: large number of fishermen in one spot.
Lie: fish caught by remarkable trick.
Fisherman catches fish with amazing contents.
Man catches fish with larger fish inside.
Lie: other unusual methods of catching fish.
Lie: fish caught with another's cries.
Lie: animals inherit acquired characteristics or conditions.
Small cart serves as back legs for crippled sow.
a: Pigs also have these carts.

d: Lie: animal's food affects him in unusual way.
a: (E.g. Pine tops: milk good for cough syrup.)

d: Lie: animals eat one another up.
Two wolves eat each other up so that only tails are left.
Lie: two birds swallow each other.
Lie: venom of animal (snake, hornet, bee) causes object to swell.
Snake strikes object, causing it to swell.
Lies: animals trained to respond to certain sounds: absurd result.
Roast pigs run around with knife and fork in back ready for eating.
Lie: roast hens fly, heads to sky, tails to ground.
Lie: cat scratches out bear's tongue.
Lie: crippled cat uses wooden leg to kill mice.
Dog and other animal chase each other in hot weather.

a: Put back together but back legs point upwards.

d: Lie: greyhounds drag mill out of water.

a: Eats the horses, is harnessed and runs in the harness.

d: Lie: large boar has bristles as long as pitchfork tines.
r: England, Scotland: *Baughman; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1879*.

a: Tusks go through tree and come out on other side.

d: Hog finds dynamite supply, eats it, walks behind mule; the mule kicks the hog.
a: The explosion kills the mule, blows down the barn, breaks windows out of house. The hog is ill for several days.

d: Lie: salesman guarantees sow to bear male, then female, then kid.
r: (First ed. +X931.) Wienert FFC LVI 84 (ET 506), 104 (ST 167); Halm Aesop No. 11.

d: Cow wears church bell for cowbell.
Cow gives so much cream that several men do nothing but skim cream.
Owner provides cow with green goggles, feeds her sawdust or snow.
Lie: cow puts bread in oven.

r: (First ed. +X1021.1.) U.S.: *Baughman, *Folk-Say I 62 (bibliography of "Paul Bunyan" stories).

d: Man plows through stump which catches the back of his pants in cleft.
a: His oxen continue to pull; he holds onto the plow, pulls the stump out of the ground.

d: Horse takes cattle out to pasture; brings them in by himself.
Trained horse as harvester and hunter.
a: He rolls in the field. Oats in his flanks; club in his tail kills birds.

d: Lie: ass with silver nose hunts hares.
Lie: goat carries one hundred cartloads of grease.
Lie: man carried through air by geese.
Hawk flies away with geese on a line.
a: They have been tied together as a protection.

d: Bumblebees imported to rout mosquitoes; the two insects crossbreed and have stingers on both ends.
Insects eat team of horses or mules, pitch horseshoes to see who gets what is left.

r: (First ed. +X1021.3.) BP II 515; *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 219.
a: Liar says that in a certain place bees are as big as sheep. And the bee-hives? The same as ours. How do the bees get in? (Various answers.)

d: Large mosquitoes fly off with kettle.
a: They have drilled through kettle. Their bills are clinched inside like nails.

d: Big mosquito with golden palace in his mouth.
The tragic death of the three gnats.
a: One of them meets his death between the horns of two struggling oxen, another because of two restless stallions, the third during a tussle between two giants.

d: Rag so full of lice it can move.
Lie: remarkable actions of big fish.
Big fish pulls man or boat.
Lie: tamed fish lives on dry land.
Lie: great snake is thought to be a log.
Lies about remarkable kinds of snakes.

a: Snake takes its tail in its mouth and rolls like a hoop toward its victim.

d: Lie: extraordinary amphibia and other animals.

a: Eaten by one larger and this in turn by crow.

r: U.S.: *Baughman; North Carolina: Brown Collection I 703.
a: Animal with two short legs on one side for convenience in living on hillsides. It can walk around the hill in only one direction.

d: Lies about plants, fruits, vegetables, and trees.
Lie: animals live inside great vegetable, usually feeding from it.
Lie: hole from which great vegetable is removed.
Lie: plants produce fruit in remarkably short time after planting.

r: (First ed. +X1025.1.) Hdwb. d. Mdrchens I 256a n. 18.
(First ed. +X1024.1.) *Type 1960D; *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 220 No. 454; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
a: (Usually matched by tale of great pot to put cabbage in.)

d: Lie: man raises eggs from eggplant.

r: (First ed. +X950.) (Cf. +X1712.) *Type 1930; *BP III 244ff.; Boccaccio Decameron VIII No. 3 (Lee 254); Irish myth: Cross; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: Thompson-Balys.
a: (Land of Cockaygne.) Land in which impossible things happen.

d: Land in which highest praise parents can earn is that they marry their children when they are babies.
Blind town, its king fourfold blind.
Lie: land where all things are sold for the same price.
Mountain of grain to be eaten through on way to Schlaraffenland.

r: (First ed. +X952.) BP III 244ff., *254ff.; Wienert FFC LVI 44ff.
a: Land where all is opposite from the usual.

d: House where omens go by contraries.

r: (First ed. +X951.) (Cf. +Z32.2.1.) Type 1940; BP IV 183; Bolte Zs. f. Vksk.
a: A place where animals and things are designated by senseless names.

d: Lies about steep slopes of mountains.
Lie: country so steep that people look up chimney to see when the cows come home.
Lies about farming on steep mountain.
Crooked railroads in mountains or hills.
Rich land: corn grows so fast that it pulls up its own roots.
Lie: fish pond supplies both fresh fish and cooked.
Lie: round river: runs in circle without outlet.
Lie: honey flows up high mountain.
Roads go over roofs of houses.
City into which only married and mothers may enter.
Village where rubies sell for four pice apiece.
Lie: year with two summers and no winter.
Lie: year with two winters and no summer.
a: It is winter all summer and in fall it gets colder.

d: Lie: mixed weather: summer in one spot and winter in another nearby.
Lies about quick change from cold to warm.
Lies about quick change in weather from warm to cold.

a: Must be thawed out by the stove.

d: Lie: frozen words thaw out in the spring.
Lie: effect of heat on animals.
Lie: weather so hot that corn pops in fields, animals freeze to death thinking it has snowed.
Lie: clouds beaten by man until they promise to water his crops thrice daily.
Lie: how dry weather affects animals.
Lie: bullfrogs several years old cannot swim   have never had water to learn in.

a: Man shingling building during thick fog shingles several feet of fog when he gets beyond the roof line.

d: Lie: fast-melting snow leaves horse dangling in air.
The man who sold dried snow for salt.
Lie: extraordinary floods produced by heavy rain.
Lie: heavy rain of boiling water melts palace.
Lie: the man under the hat, which is the only thing seen above the mud.
Lie: air from healthy climate revives dying person.
Lie: place so healthful that residents shoot man to start cemetery.
Schlaraffenland lies three miles beyond Christmas.
New backbone for the horse made from a stick.
Lie: man's organs replaced with animal's.  (Cf. +E782.)
a: He acts like animal.

d: Swallowed person is discovered in animal's stomach still alive.
Fish swallows a gourd fruit where people have taken refuge during rain; hawk swallows fish.
Lie: man swallowed by fish and later rescued alive.
Falcon and heron eaten by wild boar recovered alive from his body.
Man crawls into body of animal (after killing it) to escape cold.
a: The animal freezes back together; man must eat his way out.

d: Lie: man cuts off own head and eats it.
Man cuts off own head, picks it up and replaces it.
r: (First ed. +X927.1.) (Cf. +E783.) Type 852; BP II 514; Missouri French: Carriire.

d: Person falls from great height without injury.
Man falls from height, goes into solid rock up to knees.
Man falls and is buried in earth: goes for spade and digs self out.
r: (First ed. +X917.) *Type 1882; Ktshler-Bolte I 323; Gardner JAFL XXVII 305; U.S.: *Baughman.

d: Lie: man lifts heavy load, sinks into solid rock.
Man stays under water for long time.
Man falls through ice, has to swim two miles to come out at an air hole.

a: Falls through ice with his horse, wanders around on the river bottom, pushes his spear through ice from below and rises to the surface.

d: Person swallows pin or needle; it later emerges through skin of relative.
Lie: man makes drinking water from his own skull.
Person or animal rises into the air in defiance of gravity.
Person or animal jumps back to starting place (from midair).
Law of gravity is petrified in petrified forest.
Giants go through small hole where plant has been torn from earth.
Lie: two bullocks go where one cannot.
Lie: 900,000 roofs on point of needle.
Absurd disregard of the nature of objects.
Watch continues to run indefinitely when lost (swallowed).
Lie: people carry wine in baskets.

r: (First ed. +X961.2.) (Cf. +F843.) Type 852; BP II 513; Missouri French: Carriire.

d: Absurd disregard of the nature of non-material things.
Absurd disregard of the nature of holes.
Person pulls up old oil wells and sells them for post holes after sawing them up into short lengths.
Lie: people eat the bungholes from barrels.
Absurdity based on the nature of the object.
Lies about boats with light draft.
Boat sailing over dry river bed (rice water).
Lie: the stretching and shrinking harness.
a: Man driving team with wagon uphill in rain finds on arrival at the top of the hill that the tugs of rawhide or buckskin have stretched and that the loaded wagon is still at the bottom of the hill. He unhitches the horses and throws the harness across a stump. Sometime later, or the next morning, the sun comes out and shrinks the tugs, drawing the load to the top of the hill.

d: Man cures rheumatism: puts mosquito milk in a cat's horn, stirs it with duck's crotch.
Lie: deaf, dumb, blind, and lame men catch hare.
Lie: footless man outruns swift horse.
Lie: the great loaf of bread.

r: (First ed. +X1036.) (Cf. +B31.1.1.) *Fb "zhg" III 1142a; U.S.: Baughman; India: Thompson-Balys.

d: Man in moon lets himself down.
Boy with hat of butter, clothes of paper, etc.
Man in hollow tree defends himself successfully from leopard and bear.
The boy in the hollow tree.
a: He frightens the woodchopper who leaves behind his horse.

d: Lie: plow without horse or wheels.
Lie: suckling children rock mother in cradle.
Lie: child throws down a kid.
Lie: child throws down mill-wheels from one town to another.
Lie: man cuts ice with own head.
Lie: the hunt for the lost bee.

r: (First ed. +X938.) Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 38 No. 288C*, Espinosa Jr.
a: Is years ascending steps. On last step falls and curses haste.
They ate up their churches made of cheese and bacon.

d: Lie: warrior whose horse is cut in two continues to ride on the half horse.
Lie: the great noise from the bass-viol.
